channel.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
channel.description:
I've been writing an OpenCL Ray Caster the last couple of days.
The source code can be found at my [url=https://github.com/macroing/OpenRC]GitHub Page[/url].
By default I have 500 spheres and four point lights in the scene. It runs at around 60 FPS on my machine with that.
[url=http://postimage.org/][img]http://s13.postimg.org/4f9q371ev/Open_CL_Ray_Caster_500_Spheres_with_Shading_and_Te.png[/img][/url] [url=http://postimage.org/index.php?lang=english][/url] [url=http://postimage.org/][img]http://s4.postimg.org/ub9in666l/Open_CL_Ray_Caster_500_Spheres_with_Shading.png[/img][/url] [url=http://postimage.org/index.php?lang=english][/url]

item.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Taharok: Yes, it does it during runtime. In other bindings, such as JOCL and JavaCL you would write the C code instead. It’s AMD that’s behind this library. At least initially. They made it open source, so anyone can help them expand it.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“object, post:5, topic:552605”]vortex: Yes, it’s a virez that will destroy your GPU. Edit: By the way, what graphics card do you have? Do you have OpenCL 1.1 or later?

Taharok & Eyeownyew: I’m using a library called Aparapi. It compiles the Java bytecode in the run() method and all run-reachable methods (as they call it) on the fly, to C99 code, which OpenCL is using. So there are quite a few limitations to how you can write your Java code.

Edit:

I made some changes to how you build the project and fixed some issues with running it. I had not tested to clone, build and run before. But now I have. It didn’t work, but now it does (at least for me).

I also updated your starting position in the scene, so you should hopefully see spheres when you start it, unlike before, when you had to walk around to find them.

A few new controls have been added. Press ESC to exit (it may require a few presses if you’re running in JTP (Java Thread Pool) execution mode, as it’s pretty unresponsive then). Press E to display your current execution mode to the standard output. They can be GPU or JTP (Java Thread Pool) at this time. Press T to toggle between execution modes.[/quote]

It does this during runtime? That’s ridiculous. I’m very impressed by it, actually. It sounds like a neat idea, but I’m surprised someone actually did it. Why not just use C directly? Haha, seems like a ton of effort to go through just to use Java. Meh. I see some huge limitations, too. Either way, it’s cool.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Lin: Nice! I got an Nvidia GeForce GTX 980M, so that’s probably one major factor that I get around 60 FPS. I had arount 500 - 600 FPS when the scene consisted of around 10 spheres or so. But now there are 500. And, I don’t use any acceleration structures, which I want to add at some point.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

I had to download the latest aparapi binaries to get the GPU mode to run properly. Once I did I got ~12 fps using an AMD Radeon HD 7870 card and like 2 fps using an AMD FX 8350. Neat

Read full topic

item.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

vortex: Yes, it’s a virez that will destroy your GPU. Edit: By the way, what graphics card do you have? Do you have OpenCL 1.1 or later?

Taharok & Eyeownyew: I’m using a library called Aparapi. It compiles the Java bytecode in the run() method and all run-reachable methods (as they call it) on the fly, to C99 code, which OpenCL is using. So there are quite a few limitations to how you can write your Java code.

Edit:

I made some changes to how you build the project and fixed some issues with running it. I had not tested to clone, build and run before. But now I have. It didn’t work, but now it does (at least for me).

I also updated your starting position in the scene, so you should hopefully see spheres when you start it, unlike before, when you had to walk around to find them.

A few new controls have been added. Press ESC to exit (it may require a few presses if you’re running in JTP (Java Thread Pool) execution mode, as it’s pretty unresponsive then). Press E to display your current execution mode to the standard output. They can be GPU or JTP (Java Thread Pool) at this time. Press T to toggle between execution modes.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Taharok:

It’s super cool, but I very intrigued by this library that lets you specify Java methods for OpenCL kernel programs. How on earth does that work? Does it use the native compiled version of the Java bytecode and somehow upload that to the graphics card? I’m a bit confused because doesn’t C/C++ code configured for OpenCL or CUDA require a separate extension to compilers to compile it in an intermediary form for the graphics driver to send to the GPU for execution? How does that work to Java? I just haven’t heard of such a thing and didn’t realize this was possible.

I don’t know much about this topic at all, but from my experience with OpenGL it’s just Java bindings. Methods exist in java as replacements/extensions of the C methods, and are used in the exact same fashion. There isn’t much (if any) object oriented code when using these bindings in Java, so it’s very similar to programming in C, and the library just sort of acts like an interface. It looks like this is how Jocl works too, though I’m not sure what library object is using, and if he’s not using any (bindings, that is) I don’t know how it works.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenCL Ray Caster (3D Graphics)
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

It’s super cool, but I very intrigued by this library that lets you specify Java methods for OpenCL kernel programs. How on earth does that work? Does it use the native compiled version of the Java bytecode and somehow upload that to the graphics card? I’m a bit confused because doesn’t C/C++ code configured for OpenCL or CUDA require a separate extension to compilers to compile it in an intermediary form for the graphics driver to send to the GPU for execution? How does that work to Java? I just haven’t heard of such a thing and didn’t realize this was possible.

Read full topic
